title: Sam Darnold will help the Jets, but he's 'not a magic wand' for their struggling offense
text:
CLOSE Jets quarterback Sam Darnold has been cleared to play Sunday vs. the Cowboys after missing three games with mono. Andy Vasquez, Staff Writer, @andy_vasquez

FLORHAM PARK — Sam Darnold is the face of the Jets’ franchise. So it’s understandable that fans, teammates and coaches are excited about his return to the field Sunday against the Cowboys (4:25 p.m., CBS).

There’s hope that the 22-year-old can jump start the Jets’ struggling offense. But in the three games that Darnold missed with mononucleosis, things were bad enough that it’s obvious he won’t be able to turn this thing around on his own.

“You are what your record says you are, and right now we’re not a very good offense,” offensive coordinator Dowell Loggains said. “Sam is not a magic wand. He is a really good player that is going to lift the execution of this team and he’s a really gifted player with the ball in his hands and we’re really excited to have him. But there’s still things we need to clean up, fundamentally, technically, to make sure the other 10 guys are going about their job the right way.”

The Jets (0-4) scored only nine points on offense in the three games Darnold missed. And their only touchdown was a gift: they capitalized after the Eagles muffed a punt in the red zone on Sunday. Much of that is on Luke Falk, the third-string quarterback who was forced into action after backup Trevor Siemian (ankle) as lost for the season.

New York Jets quarterback Sam Darnold (14) drops back to pass during the first half against the New Orleans Saints at MetLife Stadium. (Photo: Vincent Carchietta, USA TODAY Sports)

Falk struggled to make quick decisions and accurate throws, and didn’t lead a single scoring drive of longer than 19 yards. But it was more than just Falk. Most obviously, the offensive line was dreadful, leading to a shakeup before the Eagles game: right tackle Brandon Shell was benched for Chuma Edoga and injured left guard Kelechi Osemele was replaced by Alex Lewis.

But everyone had a hand in the struggles.

“We’re not executing the way we need to up front and it’s not always just the line,” Loggains said. “It’s a wide receiver not running the right route, it’s a [running] back chipping when he’s not supposed to chip, it’s a quarterback holding the ball too long … It’s not one thing, there’s a bunch of things. We need to clean it up as fast as we can. It needs to happen faster, we need to execute that stuff better, we need to coach it better.”

Darnold is going to make the Jets’ offense better no matter what. He’s already proven that he can make an impact at this level. But he won’t make it much better if the Jets keep making the same mistakes, and he knows it.

“I’ve said it since we’ve been together: This offense is capable of a lot, capable of scoring a lot of points,” Darnold said. “It’s just up to us as an offense to go out there and execute and do it.”

Darnold says that having two weeks of practice time to get ready for the Cowboys will be helpful. He feels like his conditioning close to where it was before the mono, and his arm feels good. But it’s been more than a month since he’s played and he knows that there will be an adjustment period.

Sam Darnold of the NY Jets during pre game warm ups before the 2019 season opener between the Buffalo Bills vs the New York Jets from MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, NJ on September 8, 2019. (Photo: Chris Pedota, NorthJersey.com-USA Today Network)

“There’s nothing like Sunday, and I think going out there and playing the first couple of series’ will be a little bit of a shock to the system,” Darnold said. “But I think I’m going to be ready and hopefully after those couple series I think I’ll feel right at home.”

Darnold felt good enough to play last week, but wasn’t cleared by doctors because his spleen was still enlarged — a common effect of mono — and susceptible to rupture, a potentially life-threatening injury. The doctors cleared him, so that’s no longer a risk. But Darold is still taking precautions.

He’ll wear specially fit padding around his abdomen, and because it doesn’t restrict his movement Darnold plans to wear it for the rest of the season. It will be a constant reminder of the mono that knocked him out for three games, but Darnold says taking a big hit to the midsection isn’t a concern for him.

“When I’m out there playing, I’m not worried about guys hitting me or anything,” Darnold said. “I’m trusting the guys up front to do their thing and I’m trusting the receivers to go out and get open when it’s time to pass the ball. So for me, it’s all about trust. When I do get hit, I know that I’m not in danger anymore. [The doctors are] letting me go out there and play because it’s safe, so I’m not worried about that.”
description: Sam Darnold is the face of the Jets’ franchise. So the excitement about his return after missing three games with mono is understandable.
